ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance of word lengths (split by spaces) is less than 2.0, indicating consistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one word that appears more than once; otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one word that appears more than once; otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts based on the statistical property of word length variance, focusing on the uniformity of word lengths within the text. In contrast, the generated rule classifies texts based on the presence of repeated words, emphasizing lexical repetition rather than word length distribution. These rules target fundamentally different features: one examines word length consistency, the other examines word recurrence. They are unlikely to produce the same classifications on most inputs, and their core concepts—length variance versus repetition—are not equivalent. Therefore, they are largely unrelated in logic and pattern detection.
